detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: If you wish to be considered for acceptance into ILS 105 Ways of Knowing, a required course of the Bachelor of Indigenous Land Stewardship, you need to submit a Positionality Statement directly through the Faculty of Forestry outlining your interest in this course, along with information on how your citizenship, nationhood or affiliation to, and/or engagement with, an Indigenous community, nation or organization has influenced your interest in this course. The Positionality Statement will be used to determine your suitability for this course and will give you an opportunity to indicate how you might see yourself engaging with and contributing to the course and learning community. Please complete the Positionality Statement questionnaire at https://ubc.ca1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_40baiVJ0KeVaF7g

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: This course is only open to students in the Bachelor of Indigenous Land Stewardship

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Introduction to the essentials of Italian vocabulary, expressions, grammar and cultural life. Focus on listening, reading, speaking and writing skills in everyday situations in the present tense. Aligned with CEFR A1 language level. 
Before registering the course, please complete Italian Language Questionnaire to determine which course level to start: https://fhis.air.arts.ubc.ca/italian-placement-questionnaire-tool/  

See the full course overview: https://fhis.ubc.ca/course-description/ital101/  

Contact us here: https://fhis.ubc.ca/undergraduate-advising-contact-form/

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This course is hybrid. Students are expected to meet with the instructor synchronously and in class on most days. A few sessions will be asynchronous/online as indicated by the instructor. 

Introduction to the essentials of Italian vocabulary, expressions, grammar and cultural life. Focus on listening, reading, speaking and writing skills in everyday situations in the present tense. Aligned with CEFR A1 language level. 
Before registering the course, please complete Italian Language Questionnaire to determine which course level to start: https://fhis.air.arts.ubc.ca/italian-placement-questionnaire-tool/  

See the full course overview:   https://fhis.ubc.ca/course-description/ital102/  

Contact us here: https://fhis.ubc.ca/undergraduate-advising-contact-form/

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Important -If you have taken or plan to take the intensive course equivalents, you will receive credit for only one of the intensive or non-intensive courses, although the final grade for both courses will be factored into your overall GPA. For further clarification, please contact the Department of Asian Studies.

Delivery Mode -This is an in-person course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as ‘in-person’ are fully in-person for the entire term, including exams, and require in-person attendance to complete. 

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

Important -If you have taken or plan to take the intensive course equivalents, you will receive credit for only one of the intensive or non-intensive courses, although the final grade for both courses will be factored into your overall GPA. For further clarification, please contact the Department of Asian Studies.

Delivery Mode -This is an in-person course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as ‘in-person’ are fully in-person for the entire term, including exams, and require in-person attendance to complete.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Important -If you have taken or plan to take the intensive course equivalents, you will receive credit for only one of the intensive or non-intensive courses, although the final grade for both courses will be factored into your overall GPA. For further clarification, please contact the Department of Asian Studies.

Delivery Mode -This is a synchronous hybrid course. Students are expected to meet on the days and times listed, either in-person or online based on the schedule set by the instructor. All courses labelled as ‘hybrid’ have a mixture of mandatory in-person and online activities as designed by the instructor. While some components are online, in-person attendance IS required to complete the course.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Important -If you have taken or plan to take the intensive course equivalents, you will receive credit for only one of the intensive or non-intensive courses, although the final grade for both courses will be factored into your overall GPA. For further clarification, please contact the Department of Asian Studies.

Delivery Mode -This is an asynchronous online course. Students are expected to complete their coursework on their own time by the deadlines set by the instructor. All courses labelled as ‘online’ are fully online for the entire term, including exams, and do NOT require any in-person attendance to complete.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This course is part of the Coordinated Arts Program, Media Studies stream,   
https://cap.arts.ubc.ca/streams/media-studies/. Students must register in both Term  
1 and Term 2 courses in CAP. 
 
This course is clustered with VISA_V 110-227, and the Media Studies sections of the CAP stream seminar CAP_V 101. For VISA_V 110-227, please register in both the lecture, and one of the following studio sections: VISA_V 110-L21, VISA_V 110-L22, VISA_V 110-L23, VISA_V 110-L24, or VISA_V 110-L25. For CAP_V 101, please register in one of the following sections: CAP_V 101-M01, CAP_V 101-M02, CAP_V 101-M03, or CAP_V 101-M04. JRNL_V 100-A_227, and CAP_V 101 do not have any additional discussion/studio sections. Follow the prompts to register in all stream seminars (1), lectures (2), and tutorials (1-2) each term. 
 
For step-by-step instructions, please visit: https://cap.arts.ubc.ca/program/registration/ 
 
If you encounter any issues with registration into CAP, please contact us at support.fyip@ubc.ca

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Instructions for BKIN students: When a course becomes full, registration in the associated waitlist in Workday will become an option. When a seat becomes available, Workday will automatically offer it to a student who meets any restrictions on the seat, ordering students by registration date. Each offer expires after 24 hours. To accept an offer, you must be able to register for a primary or "lecture" section for the course and any secondary sections like a "lab" or "tutorial/discussion"

Instructions for non-BKIN students: Seats in all undergraduate KIN courses are initially restricted to students in the BKIN degree program at the start of the registration period. Non-BKIN students must first register in the associated waitlist section for any course they hope to be considered for a seat in. Please note that being on a waitlist does not guarantee that you will be able to secure a seat. In some cases, KIN Advising may transition available restricted seats to general seats for waitlisted non-BKIN students prior to the start of term but not at the request of any individual student.

Additional support: Waitlists are adjudicated automatically in Workday, and KIN Advising cannot answer questions about any individual’s position on a particular waitlist. Please do not contact instructors to assist with course registration, as they do not have access to register students. Students can find tutorials on how to navigate registration in KIN courses here: https://kin.educ.ubc.ca/undergraduate/how-to-workday. Additional resources on navigating Workday Student, please visit: https://workday.students.ubc.ca/

Additional support: Waitlists are adjudicated automatically in Workday, and KIN Advising cannot answer questions about any individual’s position on a particular waitlist. Please do not contact instructors to assist with course registration, as they do not have access to register students. Students can find tutorials on how to navigate registration in KIN courses here: https://kin.educ.ubc.ca/undergraduate/how-to-workday. Additional resources on navigating Workday Student, please visit: https://workday.students.ubc.ca/

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Instructions for BKIN students: When a course becomes full, registration in the associated waitlist in Workday will become an option. When a seat becomes available, Workday will automatically offer it to a student who meets any restrictions on the seat, ordering students by registration date. Each offer expires after 24 hours. To accept an offer, you must be able to register for a primary or "lecture" section for the course and any secondary sections like a "lab" or "tutorial/discussion"

Instructions for non-BKIN students: Seats in all undergraduate KIN courses are initially restricted to students in the BKIN degree program at the start of the registration period. Non-BKIN students must first register in the associated waitlist section for any course they hope to be considered for a seat in. instances.text: KIN_V 160-002 - Leisure and Sport in Society

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Delivery Mode -This is a mixed hybrid course.  Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed, as well as complete supplemental asynchronous work outside of class time. This course will be delivered in a mix-mode format (2 hrs in-person every Monday, Tuesday, and Friday + 2 hrs asynchronously every Thursday). Students are expected to meet with the instructor in-person on the above listed days and times. For Thursday's class, students are required to asynchronously watch the assigned lecture video(s) and complete the assignment(s) on their own time in advance of the Friday class. The total workload for this 6-credit course remains the same as a normal class that is fully delivered in-person.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Beginning Latin I. Visit amne.ubc.ca for full course descriptions.

This course runs in Term 2 (Jan-April, 2025).

If the course is full or blocked, or if you do not meet restrictions for the available seats, please register for the waitlist. Students will be moved manually from the waitlist into the course section in order of registration. If the course is blocked but showing available seats, this is normal and means that waitlist transfer have not yet taken place. Email amne.undergrad@ubc.ca with any questions.

uiLabels.WDRES.FACETEDSEARCH.SymanSyntax:
Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
